unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking about ditching that old petrol guzzler for an EV, eh? Smart move, yaar! But hold on, before you picture yourself zipping down Marine Drive in silent bliss, let's talk about the elephant in the room (or rather, the charging point in the parking lot): EV charging.
normalised: Okay, so you're thinking about ditching that old petrol guzzler for an E V, eh? Smart move, yaar! But hold on, before you picture yourself zipping down Marine Drive in silent bliss, let's talk about the elephant in the room (or rather, the charging point in the parking lot): E V charging.

unnormalised: Firstly, don't expect to find charging stations on every street corner like chai stalls. They're growing, but not quite there yet. Think of it like finding the perfect biryani place – you gotta do some searching. Apps like PlugShare and ElectriVa can be your best friend here.
normalised: Firstly, don't expect to find charging stations on every street corner like chai stalls. They're growing, but not quite there yet. Think of it like finding the perfect biryani place – you gotta do some searching. Apps like PlugShare and ElectriVa can be your best friend here.

unnormalised: Charging speeds? Well, that depends. Slow charging (think overnight at home with a regular plug) is like having your dadi slowly feed you delicious Onam payasam – satisfying, but takes a while. Fast charging (at public stations) is more like grabbing a quick vada pav – gets the job done much faster. Expect to add around 80 km of range per hour with a decent fast charger. Cost? Could be anything from Rs. 8 per unit to Rs. 20, depending on the provider and time of day.

unnormalised: Charging at home is usually the most convenient, especially if you have a dedicated parking spot. Consider installing a wallbox charger for faster speeds. Think of it as your own personal charging mandir!
normalised: Charging at home is usually the most convenient, especially if you have a dedicated parking spot. Consider installing a wallbox charger for faster speeds. Think of it as your own personal charging mandir!

unnormalised: Range anxiety is a real thing, especially when you're planning a road trip from Mumbai to Pune. Plan your stops, and don't drain the battery to zero. Keep a buffer, just like you wouldn't finish all the jalebis at once!

unnormalised: Battery life? Most manufacturers offer warranties of around 8 years or 160,000 km. Treat your battery right (avoiding extreme temperatures and unnecessary full charges/discharges) and it'll last even longer.
normalised: Battery life? Most manufacturers offer warranties of around eight years or one hundred and sixty thousand kilometer. Treat your battery right (avoiding extreme temperatures and unnecessary full charges/discharges) and it'll last even longer.

unnormalised: Finally, remember that the EV charging infrastructure is still evolving in India. There might be hiccups along the way, but the future is definitely electric. So, do your research, plan ahead, and get ready to embrace the silent revolution! Happy driving!
